description: From French voluptuaire, or directly from its etymon Late Latin voluptuārius, from Latin voluptārius (“pleasure-seeker; agreeable, delightful, pleasant; sensual”), from voluptās (“delight, pleasure, satisfaction”) + -ārius (suffix forming adjectives from nouns). Voluptās is derived from volup (“with pleasure; agreeably, pleasantly, satisfactorily”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *welh₁- (“to choose; to want”)) + -tās (suffix forming feminine abstract nouns indicating a state of being).

adjectives.description: voluptuary (comparative more voluptuary, superlative most voluptuary)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to the seeking of sensual pleasure.
One whose life is devoted to sensual appetites; a pleasure-seeker, a sensualist.
